Am 02.02.2007 um 13=
:30 schrieb Mark Baker:
> Ok, but you needn't use text/uri-list.   text/htm=
l would work as well
> (with lots more content, of course).  The point is s=
imply that you can
> treat the die/dice as a random data source and therefo=
re a vanilla
> GET/200 exchange should suffice.

Yes :)

But what's the adv=
antage here? I'm probably not seeing it.

I understand that this has the ad=
vantage of decoupeling things even  
further than a 302 Found response does=
 in that it (the 200 Ok text/ 
uri-list) leaves the decision of calling the=
 URI (or doing whatever  
else with it) completely to the client.

So, I co=
uld see how I would want to use this approach in an (say)  
AJAX-based appl=
ication. But, as I'm planning to go with plain HTML,  
the usual browsers e=
tc. ... how would I use this?
